section.title: Overview
section.para: The Spacecraft object's Orbit tab controls the state of the spacecraft at the given epoch. The state can be set in reference to any defined coordinate system and in several representations (Cartesian, Keplerian, etc.), with automatic conversions if either is changed.

section.title: Field Descriptions

entry.para: The State Type field allows the user to configure the type of state vector that they wish to use. The State Type field has a dependency upon the Coordinate System field. If the coordinate system chosen by the user does not have a gravitational body at the origin, then the state types Keplerian, ModifiedKeplerian, and Equinoctial are not permitted. This is because these state types require a µ value.

The Coordinate System field allows the user to choose which coordinate system with which to define the orbit state vector. The Coordinate System field has a dependency upon the State Type field. If the coordinate system chosen by the user does not have a gravitational body at the origin, then the state types Keplerian, ModifiedKeplerian, and Equinoctial are not permitted. This is because these state types require a µ value.

The Epoch Format field allows the user to specify the format for defining a spacecraft's initial epoch. Epoch Format determines both the time system (TAI, TT, etc) and the time format (Modified Julian or Gregorian).

The Epoch field allows the user to specify the initial spacecraft epoch. The format of the epoch must be consistent with the Epoch Format field. If Epoch Format is of the "ModJulian" type, then the epoch is in Modified Julian format. If Epoch Format is a "Gregorian" type, the epoch is format like 01 Jan 2000 12:00:00.000. The epoch must be 04 Oct 1957 12:00:00.000 or later in all time systems (6116.0 ModJulian).
Units: Modified Julian - days, Gregorian - N/A.
The Modified Julian date offset is 2430000.0, which is different from the IAU's standard offset.
X is the x-component of the Spacecraft state in the coordinate system chosen in the Spacecraft Coordinate System field.
Y is the y-component of the Spacecraft state in the coordinate system chosen in the Spacecraft Coordinate System field.
Z is the z-component of the Spacecraft state in the coordinate system chosen in the Spacecraft Coordinate System field.
VX is the x-component of the Spacecraft velocity in the coordinate system chosen in the Spacecraft Coordinate System field.
VY is the y-component of the Spacecraft velocity in the coordinate system chosen in the Spacecraft Coordinate System field.
VZ is the z-component of the Spacecraft velocity in the coordinate system chosen in the Spacecraft Coordinate System field.

section.para: NOTE: Default values for the remaining state types are obtained through transformations of the default Cartesian spacecraft state values. The Keplerian, ModifiedKeplerian, and Equinoctial are dependant on the origin of the CoordinateSystem, because the state types require a µ value.

entry.para: The SMA field is the spacecraft orbit's osculating Keplerian semimajor axis in the coordinate system chosen in the Spacecraft Coordinate System field. SMA must be strictly greater than 1 m or less than -1 m to avoid numerical issues in the conversions to other state types. For circular and elliptical orbits ( 0 <= ECC < 0.9999999 ) SMA should only be greater than 1 m and for hyperbolic orbits (ECC > 1.0000001) SMA should be less than -1 m. GMAT does not support the creation of parabolic orbits.

The ECC field is the spacecraft orbit's osculating eccentricity. For circular or elliptic orbits, ECC must be greater than or equal to 0.0, and less than or equal to 0.9999999 to avoid numerical issues in the conversion to other state types as the Keplerian elements are undefined for parabolic orbits. For hyperbolic orbits ECC must be greater than or equal to 1.0000001. See also the SMA description.
The INC field is the spacecraft orbit's osculating inclination, in degrees, with respect to the selected coordinate system.
The RAAN field is the spacecraft orbit's osculating right ascension of the ascending node, in degrees, with respect to the selected coordinate system.
The AOP field is the spacecraft orbit's osculating argument of periapsis, in degrees, with respect to the selected coordinate system.
The TA field is the spacecraft orbit's osculating true anomaly.
The RadPer field is the spacecraft orbit's osculating radius of periapsis. RadPer must be greater than zero.
The RadApo field is the spacecraft orbit's osculating radius of apoapsis. RadApo must be strictly greater than or less than zero. When RadApo is negative, the orbit is hyperbolic.

The h field is the projection of the eccentricity vector onto the yep axes. The Fep system is a system used in calculating the equinoctial elements and is beyond the scope of this discussion. The GMAT Mathematical Specifications document discusses Fep and the calculation of the equinoctial elements in detail.

The k field is the projection of the eccentricity vector onto the xep axes. The Fep system is a system used in calculating the equinoctial elements and is beyond the scope of this discussion. The GMAT Mathematical Specifications document discusses Fep and the calculation of the equinoctial elements in detail.

The p field is the projection of the N vector onto the yep axes. The N vector and the Fep system are used in calculating the equinoctial elements and are beyond the scope of this discussion. The GMAT Mathematical Specifications document discusses N and Fep and the calculation of the equinoctial elements in detail.

The q field is the projection of the N vector onto the xep axes. The N vector and the Fep system are used in calculating the equinoctial elements and are beyond the scope of this discussion. The GMAT Mathematical Specifications document discusses N and Fep and the calculation of the equinoctial elements in detail.
The MLONG field is the the spacecraft's mean longitude. The GMAT Mathematical Specifications document discusses mean longitude and the calculation of the equinoctial elements in detail.

section.title: Behavior when Changing the Coordinate System
section.para: When you select a Coordinate System for a spacecraft, you specify the origin and axes set with respect to which the state is defined. When you change the coordinate system via the GUI, the GUI performs the conversion from the initial coordinate system to the new system. Similarly, when you specify a state component via the script, that state component is set in the coordinate system defined in the CoordinateSystem field. When the script lines above are executed in a script, GMAT converts the state to the specified coordinate system, in this case EarthFixed, sets the X component to 1000, and then converts the state back to the internal representation.

section.title: Behavior when Changing the State Type/Representation
section.para: When you select a state type (also called state representation) for a spacecraft you select the state representation to input state data from available types such as Cartesian, Keplerian, and Equinoctial to name a few. Internally, GMAT uses the Cartesian state representation of a spacecraft with respect to a reference celestial body and expressed with respect to the MJ2000 Earth Equator. When you change the state type via the GUI, the GUI performs the conversion from the initial type to the new type. When you specify a state component via the script, that state component is set in the coordinate system defined in the CoordinateSystem field. For example, the following lines would result in the SMA of MySat to be set to 7000, in the EarthFixed system.

When the script lines above are executed in a script, GMAT converts the state to the specified coordinate system and then to the specified state type -- in this case EarthFixed and Keplerian respectively -- sets the INC component to 25, and then converts the state back to the internal representation.

section.title: Behavior when Changing the Epoch
section.para: When you select an Epoch Format for a spacecraft, you define the time system (TAI, UTC, etc.) and whether the epoch is expressed in the Gregorian or Modified Julian format. When you specify the Epoch, you define the initial epoch of the spacecraft in the specified coordinate system and state representation.

If your choice for a spacecraft's coordinate system is a time varying system such as the EarthFixed system, then when you change the spacecraft's epoch, you also change the spacecraft's inertial state representation.
